projects.spatial.nodes

Class PRQuadGrayNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.spatial.nodes.PRQuadNode
      • projects.spatial.nodes.PRQuadGrayNode

  • public class PRQuadGrayNode
extends PRQuadNode

    A PRQuadGrayNode is a gray ("mixed") PRQuadNode. It maintains the following invariants:

    • Its children pointer buffer is non-null and has a length of 4.
    • If there is at least one black node child, the total number of KDPoints stored by all of the children is greater than the bucketing parameter (because if it is equal to it or smaller, we can prune the node.

    YOU ***** MUST ***** IMPLEMENT THIS CLASS!

    • Method Detail

      • insert

        public PRQuadNode insert(KDPoint p,
                         int k)

        Insertion into a PRQuadGrayNode consists of navigating to the appropriate child and recursively inserting elements into it. If the child is a white node, memory should be allocated for a PRQuadBlackNode which will contain the provided KDPoint If it's a PRQuadBlackNode, refer to PRQuadBlackNode.insert(KDPoint, int) for details on how the insertion is performed. If it's a PRQuadGrayNode, the current method would be called recursively. Polymorphism will allow for the appropriate insert to be called based on the child object's runtime object.

        Specified by:
        insert in class PRQuadNode
        Parameters:
        p - A KDPoint to insert into the subtree rooted at the current PRQuadGrayNode.
        k - The side length of the quadrant spanned by the current PRQuadGrayNode. It will need to be updated per recursive call to help guide the input KDPoint to the appropriate subtree.
        Returns:
        The subtree rooted at the current node, potentially adjusted after insertion.
        See Also:
        PRQuadBlackNode.insert(KDPoint, int)

      • delete

        public PRQuadNode delete(KDPoint p)

        Deleting a KDPoint from a PRQuadGrayNode consists of recursing to the appropriate PRQuadBlackNode child to find the provided KDPoint. If no such child exists, the search has necessarily failed; no changes should then be made to the subtree rooted at the current node!

        Polymorphism will allow for the recursive call to be made into the appropriate delete method. Importantly, after the recursive deletion call, it needs to be determined if the current PRQuadGrayNode needs to be collapsed into a PRQuadBlackNode. This can only happen if it has no gray children, and one of the following two conditions are satisfied:

        1. The deletion left it with a single black child. Then, there is no reason to further subdivide the quadrant, and we can replace this with a PRQuadBlackNode that contains the KDPoints that the single black child contains.
        2. After the deletion, the total number of KDPoints contained by all the black children is equal to or smaller than the bucketing parameter. We can then similarly replace this with a PRQuadBlackNode over the KDPoints contained by the black children.
        Specified by:
        delete in class PRQuadNode
        Parameters:
        p - A KDPoint to delete from the tree rooted at the current node.
        Returns:
        The subtree rooted at the current node, potentially adjusted after deletion.

      • search

        public boolean search(KDPoint p)
        Description copied from class: PRQuadNode
        Searches the subtree rooted at the current node for the provided KDPoint.
        Specified by:
        search in class PRQuadNode
        Parameters:
        p - The KDPoint to search for.
        Returns:
        true if p was found in the subtree rooted at the current nodes, false otherwise.

      • height

        public int height()
        Description copied from class: PRQuadNode
        Return the height of the subtree rooted at the current nodes. The height is defined similarly to AVL trees, as follows:
        1. The height of a null tree (no nodes) is -1 (minus 1).
        2. The height of a tree that consists of a single node (a "stub" tree) is 0 (zero).
        3. The height of a tree that consists of four children is the maximum height of its children plus one.

        Specified by:
        height in class PRQuadNode
        Returns:
        the height of the subtree rooted at the current node.
